text:
:hammer_and_wrench: What tools are part of your content marketing workflow? Here's what we use:

1. ClickUp - managing content projects
2. Ahrefs - keyword research
3. Content Harmony - create our content briefs
4. Google Docs - collaborative writing, especially with freelance writers
5. Writer - alternative to Grammarly that also has a great "style guide" feature (great if you're using freelance writers)
6. MarketMuse - SEO analysis and make sure content is optimized for search - also good for finding content update opportunities
7. Wordable - (full disclosure: it's our tool) but we use this for content publishing - take our Google Docs and export to Wordpress super quickly

elements.text: What tools are part of your content marketing workflow? Here's what we use:
ClickUp - managing content projects
Ahrefs - keyword research
Content Harmony - create our content briefs
Google Docs - collaborative writing, especially with freelance writers
Writer - alternative to Grammarly that also has a great "style guide" feature (great if you're using freelance writers)
MarketMuse - SEO analysis and make sure content is optimized for search - also good for finding content update opportunities
Wordable - (full disclosure: it's our tool) but we use this for content publishing - take our Google Docs and export to Wordpress super quickly

text:
We use:
1. Asana — task management/scheduling (although we're considering a switch to another software called RaveTree)
2. Ahrefs — for content strategy research and competitor analysis
3. Clearscope — for keyword research and relevant keyword lists; we also love using this to advise on suggested word counts
4. Google Docs — we create all our briefs/outlines in a Google Doc, then send it to the freelancer to write, and it's also how we deliver the article to the client to read over
5. Grammarly — I have no idea how I ever lived without Grammarly

Grammarly — I have no idea how I ever lived without Grammarly

text:
We use:

• SEMrush - keyword research & content strategy
• Topic - content briefs & content writing. This is the most important part of our content workflow 
• Google Docs - Use it for our briefs and when working with freelancers
• Grammarly - Love how useful it is for editing and catching little errors
• Asana - manages all of our project work

text:
1. Trello for product management
2. Ahrefs - SEO stuff
3. Slack (w/ Slack connect) for client conversation
4. UseTopic for content analysis and ranking optimization (best discovery in the last few years)
5. Google Data Studio / Google Analytics for reporting
That’s it - lean and effective

text:
1. ClickUp (I hate it, but it works); I think Airtable would be better for content but I let my COO make those decisions since they manage it.
2. Ahrefs & Semrush (Keyword Research)
3. Custom Tools we’ve built to: 
    a. Generate additional keywords by looping through autosuggest results with modifiers.
    b. Cluster keywords together algorithmically and predict search intent.
    c. Tag the keyword groups as needing new content, optimization opportunities, cannibalization issues.
    d. Calculate an opportunity score by position (calculating CTR rates by position) + the financial opportunity (by taking into account conversion value, LCV, AOV, etc.) 
    e. Financial models with upper/lower bounds to get buy in from stakeholders (we use Causal for this).
    f. Calculate a personalized difficulty score by looking at current ranking positions, similarity between clusters, and overall SERP competitiveness.
    g. BigQuery + Tableau: Calculate link velocity, type, anchor text, etc. to determine what it will cost to get the links we need for the keyword clusters.
4. Then we use Google Docs to write the content.
5. Grammarly and Hemingway for copyediting.
6. Loom & Zoom for communication.
7. MarketMuse for further optimization.
8. Another internal tool for internal linking opportunities.
9. Photoshop/Illustrator/Canva for graphic design assets.
10. Process Street + Guru for SOPs/Wikis to reference when going through the process.

elements.text: ClickUp (I hate it, but it works); I think Airtable would be better for content but I let my COO make those decisions since they manage it.
Ahrefs & Semrush (Keyword Research)
Custom Tools we’ve built to:
Generate additional keywords by looping through autosuggest results with modifiers.
Cluster keywords together algorithmically and predict search intent.
Tag the keyword groups as needing new content, optimization opportunities, cannibalization issues.
Calculate an opportunity score by position (calculating CTR rates by position) + the financial opportunity (by taking into account conversion value, LCV, AOV, etc.)
Financial models with upper/lower bounds to get buy in from stakeholders (we use Causal for this).
Calculate a personalized difficulty score by looking at current ranking positions, similarity between clusters, and overall SERP competitiveness.
BigQuery + Tableau: Calculate link velocity, type, anchor text, etc. to determine what it will cost to get the links we need for the keyword clusters.
Then we use Google Docs to write the content.
Grammarly and Hemingway for copyediting.
Loom & Zoom for communication.
MarketMuse for further optimization.
Another internal tool for internal linking opportunities.
Photoshop/Illustrator/Canva for graphic design assets.
Process Street + Guru for SOPs/Wikis to reference when going through the process.

text:
I work for a fintech / crypto company, and we have some admittedly pretty rigid security standards (operating out of Europe) and typically ask that *any* tools we use fill out a short form regarding security practices etc. It’s not ideal, but non-negotiable from what I understand.

It seems Ahrefs has a public policy of not filling out any forms, but unfortunately this means we can’t use the tool. :disappointed: Obviously, I believe Ahrefs is THE standard for all things content and SEO and I understand their POV, but kinda stuck on what to do. Does anyone else have any experience with this specifically - perhaps getting Ahrefs to make an exception? Maybe someone in here from Ahrefs can help?

Thanks!

*not looking for ways to convince the team we don’t need to have them fill out a form.

text: Do you plan on importing or connecting your company’s data to Ahrefs? I’m not even sure if that’s possible, so excuse my naïveté. But if there’s no data sharing with Ahrefs, then there’s no point in the form. It’s like asking Google to sign a form because you use the search engine to find information.

text:
1. ClickUp - managing content projects and for freelancers to submit invoices (I also hate Clickup, but we use it company-wide)
2. Notion - content process documentation and department wiki, how-tos
3. SEMR/Ahrefs - keyword research
4. Google Docs - copy gets submitted by freelancers, plus we’re a fully remote org, everything is GSuite
5. Google Sheets - Editorial calendars/client-facing project tracking
6. Grammarly - backup editor (we take it with a grain. I use the desktop version and paste copy into it—the Gdoc plugin is a reliable disappointment)
7. Clearscope - Content briefs, light keyword research, competitor analysis, and we supply optimize links to our writers
8. Google Data Studio - custom in-house dashboards that pull warehoused GSC data to track performance of published content/URLs
Edit: Now y’all got me :eyes: Content Harmony. Gonna try the briefs demo.
